title: Bulgaria legend Hristo Stoichkov breaks down in tears on TV as he discusses racist abuse
text:

Ex-Bulgaria player Hristo Stoichkov appeared to cry on television while speaking about the shameful scenes in Sofia during England's 6-0 win over his country.

Stoichkov won 83 caps for Bulgaria between 1986-1999 and is widely regarded as one of the most talented players of his generation.

Monday night's match was stopped twice after Bulgaria supporters aimed monkey chants and Nazi salutes at England's black players, and UEFA have opened disciplinary procedures for a number of charges.

When asked on American Spanish sports channel TUDN about what the solution to the racism should be Stoichkov said: "That fans are not allowed in the stadium or even heavier punishments.

(Image: tudnusa/Instagram)

(Image: tudnusa/Instagram)

"Like in England for years. Five years without going to stadiums. People don't deserve to suffer."

The 53-year-old then appeared to break down in tears, and the conversation moved on to another guest.

It is thought Stoichkov was referring to the ban UEFA placed on English clubs from European competition in the aftermath of the Heysel disaster in 1985.

Since the disgraceful events of Monday police have arrested six fans thought to have been responsible for the abuse and have identified a further nine, who are under police investigation.

Bulgaria manager Krasimir Balakov, meanwhile, has apologised for the fans' actions despite initially appearing to play down the severity of it.

He originally said he had not heard any abuse, but on Wednesday he issued a public statement which read: "My comments prior to the game versus England – that Bulgaria did not have trouble with racism – were based on the fact that the local championship has not seen such an issue on a large scale.

(Image: tudnusa/Instagram)

"There might have been isolated cases, but it is definitely not something that you see at the stadium.

"The majority of football fans do not participate in such chants and I believe this also to have been the case in the game against England.

"I would like to state one thing very clearly – since there have been reported cases of racial discrimination at the stadium in Sofia I, as Bulgaria national team head coach, would like to offer my sincere apologies to the English footballers and to anyone who felt offended."
description: The former Barcelona forward was appearing on sports channel TUDN and appeared overwhelmed at one point
